awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Hybrid-Compatible Deformation Processing of Performance Critical Components
awd_abstract_narration:
Additive manufacturing has emerged as a viable route for fabricating complex machine components that have important applications in the aerospace, defense, automotive and energy sectors. Unfortunately, machine components made through additive manufacturing are often unreliable due to internal defects. This prohibits their industrial use as defective components can respond to normal service conditions in unexpected ways or fail prematurely. This award supports research to establish a novel hybrid-additive method for fabrication of defect-free components, and therefore directly impacts economic welfare and national security. This hybrid approach will repair defects using local severe deformation. Modeling efforts that will support this research will enable rapid fabrication of high quality additively manufactured components. The project will also support several classroom teaching initiatives including those focused at the K-12, undergraduate and graduate levels. These include (i) incorporation of research results into an interactive educational computer game and (ii) dissemination through short video-scribe movies available for viewing in open social media platforms.
 
The goal of this project is to facilitate defect control in additively manufactured components through hybrid post-processing methods. For achieving this goal, the methodology will involve systematic use of plastic deformation in interwoven steps during additive manufacturing for mitigation of volumetric defects. Modeling efforts will involve detailed characterization of material microstructure evolution under graded plastic strain. Microstructure parameters of interest include grain structure and defect structure. The deformation response of these parameters will be studied using in situ loading platforms that will work with existing electron microscopes and X-Ray computed tomography machines. Deformation strain fields will be characterized using digital image correlation through secondary electron imaging. These strain fields will be correlated with the evolving micro-structure parameters that will be characterized simultaneously. A process modeling framework for prediction of the surface microstructure as a function of processing conditions will be validated and used to determine optimal hybrid strategies for post processing additively manufactured microstructures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Additive manufacturing has emerged as a viable route for fabricating complex machine components that have important applications in the aerospace, defense, automotive and energy sectors. Unfortunately, machine components made through additive manufacturing are often unreliable due to internal defects. This prohibits their industrial use as defective components can respond to normal service conditions in unexpected ways or fail prematurely. Prior to this project, the impact of internal defects in additively manufactured materials was not well understood. Further, methods to mitigate these defects were not readily available. To address these gaps, the goal of the research project was to investigate and establish a new novel hybrid-additive method for fabrication of defect-free components. The hybrid manufacturing approach is intended to repair such defects using the processing capabilities of localized remelting and deformation methods. Towards this goal, the objective was to understand what features of defects limit performance in additively manufactured materials and to understand the interdependence of processing history, microstructure and thermomechanical properties for the hybrid manufacturing methods to limit occurrence of such defects. The final outcome of this work is that the research established fundamental science needed to realize next-generation hybrid manufacturing methods that can control defect structure for additively manufactured materials.

To achieve this outcome, this research exploited the use of novel experimental platforms and advanced characterization methods to directly resolve defect conditions in the additively manufactured materials of interest. Localized thermal and deformation methods were employed to controllably impart graded levels of defect healing in the manufactured surfaces so to engender tunable changes in microstructure, texture, volumetric defect structure (e.g., porosity) and mechanical properties. The mechanical response of these materials were studied to quantify material performance after processing. A novel computed tomography platform was used to directly study how defects influence failure in additively manufactured materials. These data were used to inform derivation and calibration of a modeling framework to assess defect criticality for these materials. The results have profound impact on the manufacturing community as broad access to the surface modification methods of interest to the work significantly expand the design application space for additively manufactured components, particularly in increasingly challenging mechanical, thermal and chemical loading environments. The research provided processing models and characterization tools needed for product designers to accurately model variances in microstructure, defect structure and mechanical properties introduced by these processing operations. From a materials engineering perspective, the methods introduced by the research enable new capabilities for dynamic control of surface microstructure through hybrid manufacturing.

In terms of broader impact, improvements made in the end-to-end manufacture of additive manufactured components directly facilitate realization of next-generation performance systems designs through capabilities for increased system lightweighting, higher material efficiency and lower manufacturing costs. Students engaged in the research project participated in beneficial experiences with collaborating academic institutions and industrial partners through trainings and technical exchanges. Students also have developed technical skills in manufacturing and materials related project work through training on advanced manufacturing and characterization equipment. Further, educational programs were enhanced through new curriculum development for both graduate and undergraduate courses with a focus on the defects produced by additive manufacturing and their impact to performance.

 


Last Modified: 07/16/2023
Modified by: Christopher Saldana
